title: atonement
comment: Reconciliation; sin has alienated humanity from God and provoked God's anger. God has responded by providing the means of restoring this broken relationship, bringing both sides to a place where they are at one again (``at-one-ment'').

children.title: atonement, necessity and nature of
children.comment: Scripture stresses the seriousness and reality of human sin, and that human beings are unable to atone for their own sins. In his grace, God provides a means by which the situation can be remedied.

primaryrefs.comment: The punishment of subsequent generations makes God's abhorrence of sin quite clear, but the extension of his love and forgiveness ``to thousands'' puts the emphasis in these verses on God's grace and compassion.

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew word for ``great love'' means God's loving faithfulness to those within the covenant.

atonement, in OT
children.comment: The OT laid down complex regulations by which the guilt of sin could be removed through the sacrificial system. Particular emphasis was placed upon the role of the high priest, who was required to make annual atonement for the sins of the people.

seealsos.comment: The nation's sin was atoned for by sprinkling the atonement cover in the Most Holy Place with the blood of the sacrificial goat; the removal of the people's sin was symbolised by the driving of the scapegoat into the wilderness

children.title: The atonement cover

primaryrefs.comment: The locating of God's presence above the atonement cover in the tabernacle demonstrated that it was only on the basis of atonement that God could accompany his people.

children.title: Atonement was effected by the blood of the sacrifice

primaryrefs.comment: The blood signified that the life of the animal had been given in place of that of the worshipper.

atonement, in NT
children.comment: In dying for the sins of the world, Jesus Christ fulfilled and replaced the OT sacrificial system, so that all who believe in him are restored to fellowship with God. Christ is the true high priest, who finally liberates his people from the guilt of sin, by offering himself as the supreme sacrifice.
